Perceivable.Description: Provide text alternatives for non-text content.
Perceivable.Techniques: Use ALT text for images, captions for videos, transcripts for audio.

Perceivable.Description: Provide text alternatives for pre-recorded audio-only or video-only content.
Perceivable.Techniques: Provide transcripts for audio, captions for video.

Perceivable.Description: Provide captions for prerecorded video content with audio.
Perceivable.Techniques: Use closed or open captions for videos.

Perceivable.Description: Provide an alternative for video content that includes audio descriptions.
Perceivable.Techniques: Use audio descriptions or provide a full text alternative to video content.

Perceivable.Description: Provide captions for all live audio content in synchronized media.
Perceivable.Techniques: Live captioning techniques, real-time captioning services.

Perceivable.Description: Provide audio descriptions for prerecorded video content.
Perceivable.Techniques: Use descriptive narration for key visual elements in videos.

Perceivable.Description: Information, structure, and relationships should be programmatically determined.
Perceivable.Techniques: Use semantic HTML, ARIA roles, proper heading structure.

Perceivable.Description: Content should be presented in a meaningful order.
Perceivable.Techniques: Use semantic markup to maintain a logical reading order.

Perceivable.Description: Instructions should not rely solely on sensory characteristics like shape, size, color, or sound.
Perceivable.Techniques: Avoid instructions such as "click the red button" without other means of identification.

Perceivable.Description: Content must not restrict its view and operation to a single display orientation (landscape/portrait).
Perceivable.Techniques: Support both portrait and landscape modes in mobile devices.

Perceivable.Description: The purpose of input fields must be programmatically determinable for user agents.
Perceivable.Techniques: Use HTML autocomplete attributes, proper labeling of input fields.

Perceivable.Description: Color should not be the only means to convey information.
Perceivable.Techniques: Use text labels, patterns, or shapes in addition to color.

Perceivable.Description: Provide a way to stop or control audio that plays automatically for more than 3 seconds.
Perceivable.Techniques: Provide a visible control to stop or pause audio.

Perceivable.Description: Text should have a contrast ratio of at least 4.5:1 against its background.
Perceivable.Techniques: Use high-contrast color schemes, tools to check contrast ratios.

Perceivable.Description: Text must be able to be resized up to 200% without loss of content or functionality.
Perceivable.Techniques: Use responsive design techniques, avoid fixed font sizes.

Perceivable.Description: Use text instead of images of text, except where an image is essential.
Perceivable.Techniques: Replace images of text with actual text, allow text to be resizable.

Perceivable.Description: Content should be viewable without horizontal scrolling at 320px wide (for mobile devices).
Perceivable.Techniques: Use responsive design to ensure content adjusts for small screens.

Perceivable.Description: Non-text elements (UI components, graphics) should have a contrast ratio of at least 3:1.
Perceivable.Techniques: Ensure buttons, icons, and other interactive elements have sufficient contrast.

Perceivable.Description: Users should be able to override text spacing without loss of content or functionality.
Perceivable.Techniques: Allow for custom line height, letter spacing, word spacing in text.

Perceivable.Description: Content triggered by hover or focus should be dismissible, hoverable, and persistent.
Perceivable.Techniques: Ensure popups or tooltips can be interacted with or dismissed by the user.

Operable.Description: Ensure all functionality is available from a keyboard.
Operable.Techniques: Make sure navigation, forms, and other interactive elements can be accessed via keyboard.

Operable.Description: Users should not be trapped in a part of the page using only a keyboard.
Operable.Techniques: Ensure focus can move both into and out of all interactive elements.

Operable.Description: Character key shortcuts should be able to be turned off or remapped by the user.
Operable.Techniques: Provide options for users to disable or change keyboard shortcuts for controls.

Operable.Description: Users should be able to adjust or turn off time limits.
Operable.Techniques: Provide options to extend, disable, or get warnings about time limits in forms or content.

Operable.Description: Users should be able to pause, stop, or hide any moving, blinking, or scrolling content.
Operable.Techniques: Provide controls to stop animations or auto-scrolling content.

Operable.Description: Content should not flash more than three times per second unless it is below the general flash threshold.
Operable.Techniques: Use tools to test for flashing elements that may trigger seizures.

Operable.Description: Provide a way for users to skip repeated blocks of content.
Operable.Techniques: Provide 'skip to content' links at the top of pages.

Operable.Description: Web pages should have descriptive and informative titles.
Operable.Techniques: Ensure each page has a unique and meaningful title.

Operable.Description: Navigation order should be logical and intuitive.
Operable.Techniques: Ensure keyboard focus moves in a consistent, logical order.

Operable.Description: The purpose of each link should be clear from the link text.
Operable.Techniques: Use descriptive link text, avoid vague terms like 'click here.'

Operable.Description: Provide more than one way to locate a webpage within a set of pages.
Operable.Techniques: Offer search functions, site maps, and breadcrumbs.

Operable.Description: Headings and labels should be descriptive and helpful.
Operable.Techniques: Use descriptive headings and form labels to make content easy to navigate and understand.

Operable.Description: Ensure complex gestures (e.g., multi-touch) can be operated with a single pointer.
Operable.Techniques: Provide alternatives to multi-touch gestures, like tap or click options.

Operable.Description: Ensure users can cancel actions performed by touch (e.g., dragging).
The visible text label of UI components should match their accessible name.
Operable.Techniques: Ensure ARIA labels for buttons and forms match their visible text labels.

Understandable.Description: The language of the content must be programmatically determined.
Understandable.Techniques: Use the lang attribute to specify the page's language.

Understandable.Description: Elements should not change unexpectedly when they receive focus.
Understandable.Techniques: Ensure forms or links do not trigger actions simply by receiving focus.

Robust.Description: Ensure that web pages are well-formed and can be reliably interpreted by assistive technologies.
Robust.Techniques: Use valid HTML markup, close all tags correctly.
